title: 110_hr244
content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. The disparity in investment between the US and its trading partners is leading to declining educational performance in the US compared to other countries in a global marketplace. In an increasingly global and competitive marketplace, United States-based businesses struggle to fund worker education and training, unlike their counterparts in other countries. The current global workforce environment puts pressure on domestic companies to utilize highly educated knowledge workers from other countries. It is crucial for the United States government to reverse this trend to preserve national security, a strong middle class, and the welfare of workers, while remaining competitive globally through public-private partnerships. Public-private partnerships in the United States, like the research and development tax credit, help advance the needs of citizens, businesses, and communities. Businesses excel at training the workforce by adapting to new methods and eliminating ineffective programs, especially with a large number of baby boomers retiring in the next 20 years. The United States aims to train its workforce for high-paying information and communications technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers. The Act encourages businesses and individuals to invest in education and training for knowledge workers in professions like information or communications. The United States aims to train its workforce for high-paying information and communications technology jobs by encouraging employers to invest in education and training for workers in various fields. This will help maximize training dollars and improve the utilization of newly acquired skills. SEC. 30D. Information and Communications Technology Education and Training Program Expenses. This section encourages employers to invest in education and training for workers in various fields to prepare them for high-paying ICT jobs. The tax code allows a credit of 50% of information and communications technology education and training expenses for the benefit of employees or individuals. The credit is subject to limitations and coordination with the employer. The tax code allows a credit for education and training expenses, with limitations on the amount that can be claimed. The maximum amount allowed is $4,000, or $5,000 for expenses related to programs in designated zones. The tax code provides a credit for education and training expenses, with a maximum amount of $4,000 or $5,000 for expenses in designated zones like renewal communities or disaster areas. Eligibility criteria include schools where at least 50% of students qualify for free or reduced-cost lunches. The tax code offers a credit for education and training expenses in designated zones like renewal communities or disaster areas, including rural enterprise communities, Rural Economic Area Partnership Zones, areas under Indian tribal government jurisdiction. The tax code provides a credit for education and training expenses in designated zones, including areas under Indian tribal government jurisdiction and for small employers. Information technology education and training program expenses are defined as expenses related to participation in such programs. The tax code allows for a credit for education and training expenses incurred by the taxpayer or their employees in information and communications technology programs. This includes expenses for coursework, certification testing, programs registered by the Department of Labor, and other essential skill assessment expenses. The term 'information technology education and training program' refers to training in information and communications technology workplace disciplines or other skills. A 'training program' in information and communications technology or other skill sets is provided in the United States by accredited institutions or private sector organizations. An employer-owned information technology training organization provides industry-recognized training programs to employees. No other deductions or credits are allowed for expenses covered by this training credit. The amount considered for the credit shall be reduced by IT education and training program expenses. Rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 apply. The credit cannot exceed the difference between the regular tax reduced by other credits and the tentative minimum tax for the year. The table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a clerical amendment. Sec. 30D. Information and communications technology education and training program expenses. Effective Date: Amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2006. Eligible Educational Institution. The amendment defines an eligible educational institution as one described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 or a commercial information and communications technology training provider. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code changes the reference from section 25A(f)(2) to section 25A(f)(2)(A). The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING CERTIFICATION ADVISORY BOARD. Establishment of Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury. Board members must be associated with IT certification and training associations, not federal government employees. The Board meets at least annually and elects a Chairperson from its members who is a member of an IT industry trade association. Duties include developing guidelines for computer technology. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, established with up to seven members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury, develops guidelines for college courses in computer science and related subjects. They also create a list of IT training and certifications eligible for tax credits under the Internal Revenue Code. Board members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Board members are reimbursed for travel expenses, including per diem, while away from their homes or regular places of business. The termination of the Board is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
